title: Cryo-EM Reconstruction of Tail and Capsid of Stx Bacteriophage Phi24B
content: Shiga toxin-encoding bacteriophages (Stx phages) are responsible for converting the pathogenic profiles of their bacterial hosts. Most of Stx phages are lambdoid bacteriophages. Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC), causes severe hemorrhagic colitis disease which is, in some cases, complicated by a life-threatening hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) leading to long-term disability and mortality of patients. Although the global incidence of STEC infection is low, severe disease and death occurs in an unacceptably high proportion of infected individuals: 10% and 3–5%, respectively. Bacteriophage vB_EcoP-24B (hereafter referred to as phi24B) is well-characterized since its initial isolation following induction from a clinical STEC isolate of E. coli O157:H7 [1]. The genome and physiology of phi24B-related phages were extensively studied (recently reviewed in [2]), however the structural organization of phi24B virion remains poorly understood, most of the structural proteins encoded by the phage’s genome are not identified.
